definition[0]: to make something happen very quickly, especially a series of events
note[0]: trigger a memory (=make you suddenly remember something)
example[0]: The assassination triggered off a wave of rioting.
example[1]: Certain forms of mental illness can be triggered by food allergies.
example[2]: His action triggered a massive response from the government.
definition[1]: to make something such as a bomb or electrical system start to operate
example[3]: The burglars fled after triggering the alarm.
definition[2]: the part of a gun that you pull with your finger to fire it
example[4]: He took aim and squeezed the trigger.
definition[3]: to make something start happening, especially a series of events
example[5]: The move could trigger a rush by investors to buy annuities.
example[6]: a sales rush triggered by cuts in interest rates
definition[4]: to be the thing that quickly causes something to happen, especially a problem
example[7]: A quick-fix solution could be a trigger for higher inflation.
